isis.stitle: INTERNATIONAL RIDE OPTIMIZED SUSPENSION (IROS) - HEIGHT CONTROL VALVE - CHECKING RIDE HEIGHT PROCEDURE

svcproc.title: CHECKING RIDE HEIGHT PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: Procedure for checking air spring height on the International Ride Optimized Suspension (IROS):

note.para: Chassis ride height is not measured directly. Instead, axle travel measurement will be taken. Specifications for axle travel have been calculated to result in the correct chassis ride height.

step1.para: Park the vehicle unloaded on a level surface with a light application of the brakes.
Do not apply the parking brake. Chock wheels to prevent vehicle movement.
Make sure at least 100 psi is in the vehicle air system, and then shut off engine.
Dump air from system, then re-pressurize and allow it to return to the ride height. (See Ride Height Adjustment Section.)
To measure the axle travel you will need a tape measure that will remain rigid when extended to 6 inches and one (1) 6-inch straight edge such as a piece of 3/8" flat bar.
Measurements are taken at the air spring assembly closest to the height control valve (usually forward left).

Measure the vertical distance from the bottom of the straight edge that is resting against the u-bolts, to the bottommost position of the axle stop. There should be no angle created between the two measurement points.
The measurement you obtain should fall within the values listed in the tables.
If they do not fall within the listed values on the table, the height control valve will need to be adjusted as per the instructions listed in the Ride Adjustment Section of this service manual.
